title: Git line-ending settings affect test results
body:
Reporting a minor problem. Depending on the line endings of the OS, some tests fail (e.g. `test_MafIO_index`). You can see the issue on the GHA branch [here](https://github.com/JoaoRodrigues/biopython/runs/1372046459?check_suite_focus=true), or in detail:
```
======================================================================
ERROR: test_correct_retrieval_1 (test_MafIO_index.TestSpliceGoodMAF)
Correct retrieval of Cnksr3 in mouse.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "D:\a\biopython\biopython\Tests\test_MafIO_index.py", line 671, in test_correct_retrieval_1
    result = self.idx.get_spliced(
  File "D:\a\biopython\biopython\build\lib.win-amd64-3.8\Bio\AlignIO\MafIO.py", line 648, in get_spliced
    fetched = list(self.search(starts, ends))
  File "D:\a\biopython\biopython\build\lib.win-amd64-3.8\Bio\AlignIO\MafIO.py", line 620, in search
    raise ValueError(
ValueError: Expected 3185728-3185797 @ offset 1974167, found 3185634-3185640

----------------------------------------------------------------------
```

The issue comes from one of the test data files needing `LF` line endings and failing when those are `CRLF`. My local git autocrlf is set to `auto`, which masks the problem since it converts endings on checkout and commit. Running the tests manually results in this error. I can avoid it either by setting autocrlf to `false` and doing a clean `git clone` or using `dos2unix` to convert line endings forcefully.

Maybe we should add a couple of rules to `.gitattributes` to fix this, or maybe look at what the issue might be with the code itself? Having results depending on line endings doesn't sound great.

title: StructureBuilder cannot handle non-canonical altloc ordering written by PDBIO
body:
Parsing a PDB file with disordered atoms where the first instance of the disordered atom has a non-blank altloc but other instances are blank fails - second instance is ignored.  See this example:

 - PDB 5j2u, line 10598: No altloc in first instance of disordered atom H (goes from blank to `B`):
```
ATOM   9132  N   SER B 155      30.962  53.255  26.071  1.00 48.84           N
ATOM   9133  CA  SER B 155      32.293  52.794  26.445  1.00 56.65           C
ATOM   9134  C   SER B 155      33.375  53.714  25.883  1.00 50.84           C
ATOM   9135  O   SER B 155      34.387  53.970  26.534  1.00 53.74           O
ATOM   9136  CB  SER B 155      32.510  51.365  25.951  1.00 57.00           C
ATOM   9137  OG  SER B 155      33.470  50.690  26.748  1.00 59.12           O
ATOM   9138  H   SER B 155      30.485  52.658  25.676  1.00 58.61           H
ATOM   9139  H  BSER B 155      30.485  52.658  25.676  0.00 58.61           H
ATOM   9140  HA  SER B 155      32.369  52.794  27.412  1.00 67.98           H
ATOM   9141  HB2 SER B 155      31.669  50.885  26.004  1.00 68.40           H
ATOM   9142  HB3 SER B 155      32.815  51.390  25.032  1.00 68.40           H
ATOM   9143  HG  SER B 155      33.579  49.907  26.465  1.00 70.94           H
```

PDBParser will do its job right, but then PDBIO will place atom 9139 before 9138, which mangles the round-trip parsing. Looking into `StructureBuilder`, it seems the logic behind the disordered atoms could use some improvement since it checks directly for a non-blank altloc code. Although this is not 'canonical' PDB format, it's a tiny improvement to our parser to make it more robust. We should also maybe add some logic to PDBIO to write blank altlocs first, and then named ones - fixing the problem from both ends.

body:

already, or do not wish to be listed. (*This acknowledgement is optional.*)

Closes #455, closes #2134, and closes #3213. See discussions in those issues for details. In a nutshell, there were several issues with propagating methods (e.g. transform) from Entity-level to all children in a DisorderedAtom. Likewise, there were several issues with copying DisorderedAtoms and keeping all children. The two issues were linked, thus the single PR which:
- Adds a transform method to DisorderedAtom to propagate the call to all children.
- Adds a copy method to DisorderedEntityWrapper to properly copy all children.
- Changes assignment/generation of full_id on Atoms when copying detached parents (single chains).
- Adds a new test file based on each of those issues. The tests all fail (for different reasons) in the current master but pass with this PR.

title: Fix to MMCIFIO to avoid conflicts when passing set_dic after set_structure.
body:
`MMCIFIO` checks if either `set_structure` or `set_dic` are set, in this order, before deciding what to save. Thus, the following code fails to work as expected:

```python
from Bio.PDB import MMCIFIO
from Bio.PDB.MMCIF2Dict import MMCIF2Dict

parser = MMCIFIO()
fname = '1ctf.cif'

s = parser.get_structure('s1', fname)
d = MMCIF2Dict(fname)

io = MMCIFIO()
io.set_structure(s)
io.save('out.cif')  # works as expected

io.set_dic(d)
io.save('out2.cif')  # saves the structure, not the dictionary.
``` 

This PR addresses that by explictly deleting the `self.structure` attribute when calling `set_dic`. The opposite doesn't matter since 'structure' is checked first in `save()`.

title: Bug identified at PDBIO.set_structure() and solution for it
body:
Hi, 

In the current BioPython version, there are two bugs (lines 86 and 95) in the function **set_structure**() from the class **PDBIO** (Bio/PDB/PDBIO.py):

           Line 86: sb.structure[0]["A"].add(pdb_object.copy())
           Line 95: sb.structure[0]["A"].child_list[0].add(pdb_object.copy())

As you can see, it always tries to access a chain object whose id is "A". However, if one tries to save a Residue/Atom whose chain id is not "A", it raises a KeyError exception because the recently created chain (line 79) had its id updated to **pdb_object.parent.id** at line 83 (when pdb_object is a residue) or 92 (when pdb_object is an atom).

Thus, to fix this problem, move the parent_id to outside the try/except block and substitute the previous lines by

           Line 86: sb.structure[0][parent_id].add(pdb_object.copy())
           Line 95: sb.structure[0][parent_id].child_list[0].add(pdb_object.copy())

bests

title: Coerce atom serial number to an integer for PDBIO
body:
This pull request addresses issue #2913.

I added a check to PDBIO to fail if it cannot convert the serial number to a number. Also changed the mmCIF parser to read the serial number from the files and add it to the Atom object as they build the structure. This should make `preserve_atom_numbering` work for mmCIF files as well, and prevent ambiguous errors when trying to write PDB files with non-numerical serials.

title: problem with parsing command line options in MuscleCommandline(clwstrict=True)
body:
### Setup

I am reporting a problem with Biopython 1.76, Python 3.7.7 and operating system CentOS7

```
>>> import sys; print(sys.version)
3.7.7 (default, May  7 2020, 21:25:33) 
[GCC 7.3.0]
>>> import platform; print(platform.python_implementation()); print(platform.platform())
CPython
Linux-3.10.0-1062.18.1.el7.x86_64-x86_64-with-centos-7.8.2003-Core
>>> import Bio; print(Bio.__version__)
1.76
```

My code which doesn't work:

```
subprocess.Popen((str(MuscleCommandline(clwstrict=True)),
                              stdin=subprocess.PIPE,
                              stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
                              stderr=subprocess.PIPE,
                              universal_newlines=True)
```

### Expected behaviour

Executes muscle (opens it to read from stdin to feed fasta files afterwards). Muscle is installed and in $PATH.

### Actual behaviour

Returns: 
`FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'muscle -clwstrict': 'muscle -clwstrict'`

However, what does work is without `clwstrict=True`. 
I could fix this problem with the `shlex` module to parse command line options before passing those to subprocess:

````
subprocess.Popen(shlex.split(str(MuscleCommandline(clwstrict=True))),
                             stdin=subprocess.PIPE,
                             stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
                             stderr=subprocess.PIPE,
                             universal_newlines=True)
```

(*Please fill this in, and provide any exception message in full*)

### Steps to reproduce

#### Errors:
```
import subprocess
subprocess.Popen((str(MuscleCommandline(clwstrict=True)),
                              stdin=subprocess.PIPE,
                              stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
                              stderr=subprocess.PIPE,
                              universal_newlines=True)
```

#### Works:
```
subprocess.Popen(shlex.split(str(MuscleCommandline(clwstrict=True))),
                             stdin=subprocess.PIPE,
                             stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
                             stderr=subprocess.PIPE,
                             universal_newlines=True)
```

title: Sphinx API documentation missing __magic__ methods
body:
e.g. https://biopython.org/docs/dev/api/Bio.Seq.html and https://biopython.org/docs/1.76/api/Bio.SeqRecord.html are missing the ``__getitem__`` documentation which describes slicing etc.

Compare with https://biopython.org/DIST/docs/api/Bio.Seq.Seq-class.html (generated with epydoc, which we intend to drop.

This is likely down to a miss-configuration in https://github.com/biopython/biopython/blob/master/Doc/api/conf.py

To build the documentation locally (see also #1803), use:

```
pip install tox
tox -c .travis-tox.ini -e api
open Doc/api/_build/html/index.html
```

title: Python 3.8 now throws an exception when modifying a dictionary while iterating
body:
Python 3.8 now throws an exception when modifying a dictionary while iterating

```
--- a/Bio/SubsMat/__init__.py
+++ b/Bio/SubsMat/__init__.py
@@ -207,7 +207,7 @@ class SeqMat(dict):
 
     def _correct_matrix(self):
         """Sort key tuples (PRIVATE)."""
-        for key in self:
+        for key in dict(self):
             if key[0] > key[1]:
                 self[(key[1], key[0])] = self[key]
                 del self[key]
```

```
$ pip install -h
...
  -e, --editable <path/url>   Install a project in editable mode (i.e. setuptools "develop mode") from a local
                              project path or a VCS url.
...
```

```
$ git clone git@github.com:biopython/biopython.git
$ cd biopython
$ pip install -e .
```

This is an unfortunate side effect of the changes in #2007, intended to help with confusing messages when C code was not compiled.

title: SeqFeature.WithinPosition instances fail to unpickle
body:
### Setup

I am reporting a problem with Biopython version, Python version, and operating
system as follows:

3.6.6 (default, Jan 26 2019, 16:53:05) 
[GCC 4.8.5 20150623 (Red Hat 4.8.5-36)]
CPython
Linux-3.10.0-693.21.1.el7.x86_64-x86_64-with-centos-7.2.1511-Core
1.74

### Expected behaviour

Instances of WithinPosition should pickle and unpickle

### Actual behaviour

Unpickling a WithinPosition instance fails with:

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-8-7e6a36b7b135> in <module>
      4 wp = SeqFeature.WithinPosition(10,10,13)
      5 p = pickle.dumps(wp)
----> 6 unpickled_wp = pickle.loads(p)

TypeError: \_\_new\_\_() missing 2 required positional arguments: 'left' and 'right'


### Steps to reproduce

I ran into this unpickling an object containing a SeqRecord derived from UniProt acc P08514, but some digging narrowed it down to:
 
import pickle
from Bio import SeqFeature

wp = SeqFeature.WithinPosition(10,10,13)
p = pickle.dumps(wp)
unpickled_wp = pickle.loads(p)


Pickle expects \_\_getnewargs\_\_() or \_\_getnewargs\_ex\_\_() to be defined for instances of classes that alter the call signature of \_\_new\_\_(cls). I assume WithinPosition inherits \_\_getnewargs\_\_() from int, but then overrides the \_\_new\_\_ signature so the two are not compatible. It looks as if several other *Position classes in this module will fail in the same way

title: Appending to bgzf files misses sequences
body:
### Setup

I am reporting a problem with Biopython version, Python version, and operating
system as follows:

```python
>>> import sys; print(sys.version)
3.6.7 |Anaconda, Inc.| (default, Oct 23 2018, 14:01:38)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Clang 4.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_401/final)]
>>> import platform; print(platform.python_implementation()); print(platform.platform())
CPython
Darwin-17.7.0-x86_64-i386-64bit
>>> import Bio; print(Bio.__version__)
1.73
```

### Expected behaviour

The script in `Steps to reproduce` outputs both of the sequences added to the bgzf file:

```
>hello
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
>there
cccccccccccccccccc
```

### Actual behaviour

It only outputs the first sequence:

```
>hello
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
```

### Steps to reproduce

Run the following script:

```
import Bio.bgzf as bgzf
from Bio import SeqIO
import gzip
import os
import os.path as op

# file to be used for testing bgzf fasta
bgz_filename = '/tmp/test.bgz'
if op.exists(bgz_filename):
    os.remove(bgz_filename)

# file to be used for testing text fasta
txt_filename = '/tmp/test.fa'
if op.exists(txt_filename):
    os.remove(txt_filename)

# write the first sequence
with bgzf.open(bgz_filename, 'ab') as f, open(txt_filename, 'ab') as f1:
    f.write('>hello\n'.encode('utf8'))
    f.write('aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa\n'.encode('utf8'))

    f1.write('>hello\n'.encode('utf8'))
    f1.write('aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa\n'.encode('utf8'))

# write the second sequence
with bgzf.open(bgz_filename, 'ab') as f, open(txt_filename, 'ab') as f1:
    f.write('>there\n'.encode('utf8'))
    f.write('cccccccccccccccccc\n'.encode('utf8'))

    f1.write('>there\n'.encode('utf8'))
    f1.write('cccccccccccccccccc\n'.encode('utf8'))

print("bgzf")
# the following should print all the lines but it only prints the
# lines for the first sequence

with bgzf.open(bgz_filename, 'rb') as f:
    bgzf_txt = f.read(1000000)
    f.seek(0)
    for line in f:
        print("line:", line)

print("gzip")
# as a control, gzip prints all the lines
with gzip.open(bgz_filename, 'r') as f:
    gzip_txt = f.read(1000000)
    f.seek(0)
    for line in f:
        print("line:", line)

if gzip_txt != bgzf_txt:
    print("ASSERTION FAILED: gzip output does not equal bgzf output")

bgz_index = '/tmp/bg.ix'
if op.exists(bgz_index):
    os.remove(bgz_index)
txt_index = '/tmp/txt.ix'
if op.exists(txt_index):
    os.remove(txt_index)

ix_bgz = SeqIO.index_db(bgz_index, bgz_filename, 'fasta')
ix_txt = SeqIO.index_db(txt_index, txt_filename, 'fasta')

print('ix_bgz', list(ix_bgz.keys()))
print('ix_txt', list(ix_txt.keys()))

assert(len(list(ix_bgz.keys())) == len(list(ix_txt.keys())))
```
If I output both sequences without opening the bgzf file twice then it works as expected. It looks like there's an issue with opening the file more than once to append data.

title: TravisCI/Tox - not installing flake8-bugbear on Python 3
body:
Looking at our logs, the TravisCI Tox configuration is intended to install ``flake8-bugbear`` when running the ``style`` tests on Python 3, but as written isn't working:

https://github.com/biopython/biopython/blob/biopython-173/.travis-tox.ini#L98

The environment is currently just ``style`` under both Python 2 and 3, there is no Python version prefix (unlike the main tests):

https://github.com/biopython/biopython/blob/biopython-173/.travis.yml#L30

This explains why when filing #2015 the system was not already reporting ``B011`` errors.

(As an aside, we'd need a similar fix if we were to start using black, see #2008, which again is Python 3 only)

title: Vector division broken in python 3.x
body:
### Setup

I am reporting a problem with Biopython version, Python version, and operating
system as follows:

```python
import sys; print(sys.version)
import platform; print(platform.python_implementation()); print(platform.platform())
import Bio; print(Bio.__version__)
```

```
python
Python 3.6.7 (default, Oct 22 2018, 11:32:17) 
[GCC 8.2.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import sys; print(sys.version)
3.6.7 (default, Oct 22 2018, 11:32:17) 
[GCC 8.2.0]
>>> import platform; print(platform.python_implementation()); print(platform.platform())
CPython
Linux-4.18.0-13-generic-x86_64-with-Ubuntu-18.04-bionic
>>> import Bio; print(Bio.__version__)
1.73
```

### Expected behaviour

I should be able to write `v = Vector(2, 2, 2) / 2` to divide a vector by a scalar.

### Actual behaviour

An error is raised: `TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for /: 'Vector' and 'int'`
It appears to be due to the fact that BioPython supplied `__div__` for Vectors, but in python 3.x we need to supply `__truediv__` and `__floordiv__` instead.  My current work-around is to call `Vector(2, 2, 2).__div__(2)`

### Steps to reproduce

simply divide a vector by an int.

title: Outdated seqtype parameter values in Bio.Align.Applications.MuscleCommandline
body:
### Description of issue 

I have found an issue where valid MUSCLE seqtype parameters values cannot be passed using MuscleCommandline(seqtype=XXX). This appears to be due to a change in MUSCLE parameter values that have not been updated in Biopython. 

The flag for nucleotide sequence in MUSCLE used to be ```-seqtype nucleo``` but ```nucelo``` has been changed to either ```rna``` or ```dna``` and ```nucleo``` is no longer valid. Normally sequence type is determined automatically (defualt: ```-seqtype auto```) and does not need to be specified, however, I am working on a project where explicitly passing the sequence type is necessary.

I'm not sure when exactly from nucleo was changed to rna/dna, however it does appears to be recent. The version 3.8 user guide (http://www.drive5.com/muscle/muscle_userguide3.8.pdf) uses the old nucleo value, while the current command line reference (https://www.drive5.com/muscle/manual/valueopts.html) uses the new rna/dna values.

### System info
Python version: 3.6.7 (v3.6.7:6ec5cf24b7, Oct 20 2018, 13:35:33) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)]
Python implementation: CPython
OS: Windows-10-10.0.17134-SP0
Biopython version: 1.73
MUSCLE version: 3.8.31 for Windows (32/64 bit)

### Code examples
The following example in python should should be valid but raises and error:
```
from Bio.Align.Applications import MuscleCommandline

# Paths
muscle_path = 'MUSCLE\\muscle3.8.31_i86win32.exe'
fasta_in = 'sequences.fasta'
fasta_out = 'output.fasta'

# Alignment
muscle_cline=MuscleCommandline(muscle_path, input=fasta_in, out=fasta_out, seqtype = 'dna')
muscle_cline()
```
Error: ```ValueError: Invalid parameter value 'dna' for parameter seqtype```

Changing seqtype to the now obsolete 'nucleo' is valid in MuscleCommandline:
```
...
muscle_cline=MuscleCommandline(muscle_path, input=fasta_in, out=fasta_out, seqtype = 'nucleo')
...
```
But this results in a MUSCLE error:
```
Bio.Application.ApplicationError: Non-zero return code 2 from 'MUSCLE\\muscle3.8.31_i86win32.exe -in sequences.fasta -out output.fasta -seqtype nucleo', 
message '*** ERROR ***  Invalid parameter -SeqType nucleo'
```

However running MUSCLE directly  from the command line is fine with '-seqtype dna':
```
~\MUSCLE\muscle3.8.31_i86win32.exe -in sequences.fasta -out output.fasta -seqtype dna
```

### Suggested fix
The allowed parameter values for ```seqtype``` in ```MuscleCommandline()``` should be updated to allow ```'rna'``` and ```'dna'```. It would probably be a good idea to keep ```'nucleo'``` as a valid parameter to support older implementations of MUSCLE.

title: Inconsistent behaviour with Seq '>' and '>=' operators
body:
### Setup

I am reporting a problem with Biopython version and operating
system as follows:

```
CPython
Linux-4.17.9-1-ARCH-x86_64-with-arch-Arch-Linux
1.73.dev0
```
The behaviour is different in Python 2 and 3

###  Behaviour

Python 3.6.6:
```
>>> from Bio.Seq import Seq
>>> 'A' > Seq('A')
False
>>> Seq('A') > 'A'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: '>' not supported between instances of 'Seq' and 'str'
```

Python 2.7.15:
```
>>> from Bio.Seq import Seq
>>> 'A' > Seq('A')
False
>>> Seq('A') > 'A'
False
```

It also impacts the `>=` operator in the same way. And it illustrates that the current Python 2 behaviour is wrong:

```
>>> Seq('A') == 'A'
True
>>> 'A' >= Seq('A')
True
>>> Seq('A') >= 'A'
False  # Should be True

```

I'm not exactly sure what changed between Python 2 and 3, but I note that `Seq`, `UnknownSeq`, and `MutableSeq` [implement](https://github.com/biopython/biopython/blob/master/Bio/Seq.py#L224) `__lt__` and `__le__` methods but not `__ge__` or `__gt__` methods (EDIT: in fact, `UnknownSeq` does not implement any of these methods currently).

So the solution might be to implement the `__ge__` or `__gt__` methods (I quickly tested this and it seemed to work). Is this the way forwards?

Also it might be that we want to restrict comparisons for both the `>`/`>=` and the `<`/`<=` case. For example, in Python 2, some pretty funky comparisons are currently allowed:

```
>>> Seq('A') < 1, Seq('A') > 1
(False, True)
>>> Seq('A') < object(), Seq('A') > object()
(False, False)
```

What comparisons should be supported, perhaps only `Seq` to `Seq`,  `Seq` to string, and string to `Seq`? What about for `MutableSeq` and `UnknownSeq`?

(Presumably corresponding unit tests would be needed around [here](https://github.com/biopython/biopython/blob/master/Tests/test_seq.py#L245).)

title: parsing of anisotropic B factors in  Bio/PDB/MMCIFParser.py uses wrong mmCIF category
body:
In Bio/PDB/MMCIFParser.py

The mmCIF parser tries to parse aniso records from the mmCIF file. 
It uses _atom_site.aniso_U[1][1] to determine if an atom has aniso records. 

aniso records are separate from atom_site in mmCIF
It should use the mmCIF category _atom_site_anisotrop

See (for example)
https://www.ebi.ac.uk/pdbe/entry-files/3nir.cif

Current behavior - all structures will have aniso_flag of 0

The tests for comparing the PDB and mmCIF parsers seem to miss this.

title: Rate limit calls to NCBIWWW.qblast function

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: This should be an easy fix, suitable for beginners

body:
We simplified the delay code in ``NCBIWWW`` for Biopython 1.72,

https://github.com/biopython/biopython/blob/biopython-172/Bio/Blast/NCBIWWW.py#L162

However, this does not currently impose a delay check between calls to the ``qblast`` function, and it should.

The simplest way to do this would be to store previous call time at function level as implemented in our Entrez and TogoWS code - see https://github.com/biopython/biopython/blob/biopython-172/Bio/Entrez/__init__.py#L538 and https://github.com/biopython/biopython/blob/biopython-172/Bio/TogoWS/__init__.py#L351

title: Escaping double quotes in EMBL/GenBank feature qualifiers

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: This should be an easy fix, suitable for beginners

body:
Quoting http://www.insdc.org/files/feature_table.html#3.3

> # 3.3.3.1 Free text
> Most qualifier values will be a descriptive text phrase which must be enclosed 
> in double quotation marks. When the text occupies more than one line, a single 
> set of quotation marks is required at the beginning and at the end of the 
> text. The text itself may be composed of any printable characters (ASCII 
> values 32-126 decimal). If double quotation marks are used within a free text 
> string, each set (") must be 'escaped' by placing a second double quotation 
> mark immediately before it (""). For example: 
> ```
>               /note="This is an example of ""escaped"" quotation marks"
> ```

Currently we strip out all double quotes here on parsing:
https://github.com/biopython/biopython/blob/biopython-171/Bio/GenBank/__init__.py#L1159

And on writing just wrap as given with double quotes:
https://github.com/biopython/biopython/blob/biopython-171/Bio/SeqIO/InsdcIO.py#L313

Implementing this as per the specification should not be too complicated, but it will need new tests added.

See also the related handling of value-less qualifiers, #905

title: changed atom coordinates to numpy array to allow distance calculation
body:
This pull request addresses an issue reported on stackoverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47359764/biopython-mmtfparser-cant-find-distances-between-atoms

Atoms imported via MMTFParser have the coordinates stored as a list and not as a Numpy array which breaks the `__sub__` implementation.

title: Implements Py3-compatible rich comparison for all Bio.PDB objects
body:
This pull request addresses issue #1356 and refactors #1189 and PR #1291. It implements rich comparisons for every object of the SMCRA hierarchy, including disordered wrappers. This allows direct comparison of any two objects and allows calling the `sorted` method directly, unifying the API.

The test suite was expanded and refactored to test all these possibilities. The `a_structure.pdb` test PDB was slightly tweaked to avoid adding yet another file. I had to fix a number of other tests to accomodate these changes. All tests pass under Python 2.7 and Python 3.

Thanks @harryjubb for raising the problem that led to this fix, and @peterjc for the earlier work and usual leadership 👍

secseq = ['Val','Und','Glu','Asn','Gly','Asp','Leu','Gly','Glu','Gly','Asp','Leu','Gly','Glu','Gly','Asp','Leu','Gly','Glu','Gly','Asp','Leu','Gly','Glu','Gly','Asp','Leu','Gly']



alignments = pairwise2.align.localmx(firseq, secseq, 2, -1,gap_char = ['---'])
print(format_alignment(*alignments[0]))
```

title: Bio.pairwise.align.* docstrings
body:
As flagged on Twitter by Bede Constantinides (@Bebe on GitHub), 
https://twitter.com/beconstant/status/860079532946202624

The main docstring describes e.g. ``localxx``,

```python
>>> from Bio import pairwise2
>>> help(pairwise2)
```

However, the alignment class lacks this key information:

```python
>>> from Bio import pairwise2
>>> help(pairwise2.align)
```
```
Help on align in module Bio.pairwise2 object:

class align(builtins.object)
 |  This class provides functions that do alignments.
 |  
 |  Methods defined here:

 |  __getattr__(self, attr)

 |  ----------------------------------------------------------------------

 |

 |  Data and other attributes defined here:
 |  
 |  alignment_function = <class 'Bio.pairwise2.align.alignment_function'>
 |      This class is callable impersonates an alignment function.
 |      The constructor takes the name of the function.  This class
 |      will decode the name of the function to figure out how to
 |      interpret the parameters.
```

As do the methods,

```python
>>> from Bio import pairwise2
>>> help(pairwise2.align.localxx)
```
```
Help on alignment_function in module Bio.pairwise2 object:

localxx = class alignment_function(builtins.object)
 |  This class is callable impersonates an alignment function.
 |  The constructor takes the name of the function.  This class
 |  will decode the name of the function to figure out how to
 |  interpret the parameters.

 |  penalty2args = {'c': (['gap_A_fn', 'gap_B_fn'], 'gap_A_fn and gap_B_fn...
```

Initially we could perhaps move/copy key bits of the module docstring into the class docstring?

Adding docstrings to the class' methods like ``localxx`` look tricky given the current ``__getattr__`` based approach (modern Python likely offers a more elegant way to do that).

title: Bio.PDB sorting not tested and Python 2 only
body:
The ``cmp`` function is Python 2 only, sorting using a key function is the preferred idiom for Python 2 and 3.

``Bio/PDB/Chain.py`` class ``Chain`` uses ``cmp`` in never used private method ``._sort```, could remove this?

``Bio/PDB/Structure.py`` class ``Structure``, same.

``Bio/PDB/Model.py`` class ``Model``, same.

``Bio/PDB/Residue.py`` class ``Residue`` defines ``._sort`` and uses in public ``.sort`` but not tested.

Spotted via flake8 tests (installed and running under Python 3),

```

Running the code on Windows 10 with the latest available MSMS executable fails because of the code calls a BASH script. This script - `pdb_to_xyzr` - seems to be mapping atom names to radii, so we might be able to add those as a table to the ResidueDepth module and have full Windows compatibility.

title: SearchIO.BlatIO assertion statements block parsing of blatx (protein query vs dnax database) PSL files
body:
Hello all, 

While working on a program to automate BLAT searches, I stumbled across this error. In short, the mismatch between the query ranges and target ranges that are inherit in blatx searches are triggering the following AssertionError:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/core/interactiveshell.py", line 2881, in run_code
    exec(code_obj, self.user_global_ns, self.user_ns)
  File "<ipython-input-34-743ae90aba50>", line 1, in <module>
    qresults = SearchIO.read('/home/manny/blatx_test.psl','blat-psl')
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/Bio/SearchIO/__init__.py", line 357, in read
    first = next(generator)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/Bio/SearchIO/__init__.py", line 314, in parse
    for qresult in generator:
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/Bio/SearchIO/BlatIO.py", line 401, in __iter__
    for qresult in self._parse_qresult():
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/Bio/SearchIO/BlatIO.py", line 492, in _parse_qresult
    hsp = _create_hsp(prev_hid, prev_qid, prev)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/Bio/SearchIO/BlatIO.py", line 354, in _create_hsp
    assert hsp.hit_end == psl['tend']
AssertionError
```
This bug was replicated by myself using various versions of BLAT (v0.33, a few revisions of v0.34, and the recent v0.35), using various genomes from UCSC (Alligator, Human, and Mouse), and using different protein queries (CDN1B and Insulin in addition to UCHL3). All of the above combinations work if one uses nucleotide queries. 

To replicate this error, run a blat search using `blat [genome.2bit] [protein query] [output.psl] -q=prot -t=dnax -out=psl` to generate the required psl file. ([Here is one such file](https://github.com/biopython/biopython/files/903515/blatx_test.psl.txt), generated by blat-ing [this protein](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/protein/48145827?report=fasta) against hg38 with the given command). Then, in python, run:

```
from Bio import SearchIO
qresults = SearchIo.read('blat_test.psl', 'blat-psl')
```

It seems like the issue comes up because of the inherit discrepancy between the range of the protein hit, and the range of the DNA target; a stopgap patch, then, might be to have an optional `dnax` parameter for blat-psl that, combined with an if-then statement, allows a bypass of the assertions in lines 351-354 of Bio.SearchIO.BlatIO. While it would be nice to have an alternative set of assertion tests in the case of blatx-derived PSL files, I can't think of any off the top of my head that wouldn't run into the same issues. 

Best, 
Juan Manuel Vazquez

title: Prevent PDBIO from writing large structures not supported in PDB format
body:
The PDB format specification imposes several limits on the number of atoms, residues, and chains that can be written to file. This is one of the reasons behind the move to the mmCIF format as the default structural data storage format. 

Since we have the ability to read both PDB and mmCIF structures, but only to write PDB files, there should be a check to prevent writing very large structures that break the format specifications: > 99.999 atoms, >9999 residues, >1 character chains, etc.

title: CIF to PDB conversion yields bad PDBs
body:
The PDB format is character delimited and the `PDBParser` relies on this spacing to determine  some things from the atom name (e.g. element). MMCIF files on the other hand are designed to be tabulated and therefore we cannot rely on 'spacing'. This is particularly important for the `Atom.fullname` attribute and has implications in writing PDB files from parsed mmCIFs. 

A possible fix is to work on `PDBIO` to pad the full atom name with an empty space for heavy atoms in ATOM records. MDtraj does something like this:

```
if len(atom.name) < 4 and atom.name[:1].isalpha() and (atom.element is None or len(atom.element.symbol) < 2):
    atomName = ' '+atom.name
```

A better fix would be to maybe just remove full name and go with name only, but this will probably break a lot of things.

title: Bio.Statistics.lowess breaks on some inputs
body:
Not sure what lowess is doing by itself in Bio.Statistics but it's nice to have a pure-Python implementation available.
In any case, it is a pity that a function supposed to smooth data fails on perfectly smooth data:

```
In [1]: lowess(arange(20), [1] * 20)
Out[1]: 
array([ nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,
        nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan,  nan])
```

(and it will also fail on weakly noisy data).

To fix this:
- the explicit matrix inversion at lines 87-89 of `lowess.py` must be replaced by a call to `numpy.linalg.lstsq`, such as `beta1, beta2 = linalg.lstsq([[A11, A12], [A12, A22]], [b1, b2])[0]`
- an explicit check for all-zeros entries must be added at the top (otherwise the algorithm gets confused by null matrices), such as `if abs(y).max() == 0: return y`.

title: CodonAdaptationIndex math domain error
body:
I get an error on certain sequences when running the CodonAdaptationIndex module from Bio.SeqUtils.CodonUsage. The error is thrown when using the cai_for_gene method. The error is:

```
File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/Bio/SeqUtils/CodonUsage.py", line 119, in cai_for_gene
    caiValue += math.log(self.index[codon])
ValueError: math domain error
```

I have figured out that the issue is when a codon in the tested sequence. If the index has the value of a codon as 0.00 and the tested sequence has that codon in it, then the error is thrown due to the math.log(0.00). E.g. if in the generated index codon CTA is 0.00 and CTA is present in the tested sequence then the error is thrown. Modifying the code of CodonUsage.py to be:

```
if codon!='ATG' and codon!= 'TGG': #these two codons are always one, exclude them.
                    if self.index[codon]!=0.00: #if the codon is 0 in the index an exception will be thrown so increment the length but do no increase the caiValue
                        caiValue += math.log(self.index[codon])
                    LengthForCai += 1
```

appears to fix the issue but I am unsure if this is the correct way to fix it.

Hope this helps.
Cheers,
Conor
